concept.shortdesc: Learn a few tips to make your text easier to translate and less likely to cause translation errors.

section.title: Clarity
section.p: A text that is easy to understand is usually also easier to translate. To make your writing clearer, use these tips:

ul.li: Avoid overly long sentences and paragraphs.

Repeat important words to avoid misunderstanding. For example, instead of writing 'If the shaft of your wand breaks, you can get a new one online,' write 'If the shaft of your wand breaks, you can get a new wand online.'
Don't describe more than one action in a sentence unless writing about strictly related actions.
Use words such as "and," "then," "but," "a," "the," "this," and "that" to make your message clear.

section.title: Grammar
section.p: You can make your text easier to understand by using certain grammatical forms. To make your writing clearer, follow these rules:

ul.li: Express actions with verbs, not nouns. For example, instead of writing 'Applying excessive force can lead to rupture of your wand,' write 'If you apply excessive force, your wand can break.'
Split clusters of nouns into smaller logical units. For example, instead of writing 'magic wand cleaning center,' write 'center for cleaning magic wands.'

section.title: Formating
section.p: Search your text for unintended linebreaks and punctuation marks (such as periods in place of commas). Translation tools may misinterpret such characters and split sentences into separate units. This can lead to translation errors and inconsistencies.
Avoid using pagebreaks and empty lines to layout your document. The same content can have a different volume in different languages.
section.note: When localizing a DITA project, always send the translators your source files rather than the output (such as PDF or HTML files).

link.desc: Learn a few tips to make images in your project easier to localize.
Learn how to organize your project to make localization easier.
Learn a few tips to make images in your project easier to localize.

concept.shortdesc: Learn about types of content that you may wish to leave untranslated.

section.title: Types of non-translatable content
section.p: When you plan the localization of your project, it is important to identify content that should be left untranslated. Here are a few examples of such content:

ul.li: proper names, such as brand names
UI text (if the UI is not localized)
legal text (may need to be handled separately)

section.note: You can use glossariesLearn the benefits of using glossaries in your localization process. to identify content that must be left untranslated.

section.title: UI text
section.p: If your project contains references to UI text, it is important to consider whether the UI is translated and if so, into which languages. If the UI is not localized, you should instruct translators on how they should approach UI text. For example, you may want them to provide a translation in brackets.

link.desc: Learn a few tips to make images in your project easier to localize.
Learn the benefits of using glossaries in your localization process.

concept.shortdesc: Learn the benefits of using glossaries in your localization process.

section.title: Consistency
section.p: Glossaries are the easiest way to improve consistency of translated text. Different translators (or even the same translator at different times) can translate the same term in various ways. Giving them a glossary of approved translations can increase the consistency of terminology in one project or different projects concerning the same product.
section.note: Most CAT tools enable automatic terminology checks to ensure a translator has used terms from the glossary. Although such checks are less useful in languages in which the same word can have various grammatical forms .

section.title: Non-translatable text
section.p: Glossaries can also specify text that should not be translated, such as brand names.

section.title: Forbidden terms
section.p: If you don't want a given term to be tarnslated in a particular way, a glossary is also a good place to specify that. For example, the word "pacemaker" can be translated into Polish as "rozrusznik", but you may want translators to use the less colloquial "stymulator" instead.

section.title: Context
section.p: Glossaries can also provide context for each term, such as its definition.

section.title: Format
section.p: Glossaries (called term bases) can be developed directly in a CAT tool. Most CAT tools have their own term base format, but you can use a universal format called TermBase eXchange (TBX) to exchange term bases between different tools.
You can also prepare a glossary as a CSV file in a spreadsheet editor and then import it into a CAT tool.

fig.title: A simple bilingual glossary developed in a spreadsheet editor

image.alt: A simple bilingual glossary developed in a spreadsheet editor

link.desc: Learn about types of content that you may wish to leave untranslated.

concept.shortdesc: Learn a few tips to make images in your project easier to localize.

section.title: Image format
section.p: If your images contain text that needs to be localized, avoid using bitmaps, such as JPG or PNG files. Instead, use SVG files. Most CAT tools can translate text embedded in SVG files.

section.title: Callouts
section.p: To simplify the localization process, avoid using descriptions within images. Instead, use numbered callouts and explain them under the image.SS

image.alt: A 'fig' DITA element containing an image with two callouts that are explained in a numbered list below the image

section.title: UI screens
section.p: If your documentation contains user interface (UI) screens, it is important to consider whether the UI is going to be localized. You may need to plan for additional steps to prepare UI screens in target languages.

link.desc: Learn a few tips to make your text easier to translate and less likely to cause translation errors.
Learn a few tips to make your text easier to translate and less likely to cause translation errors.
Learn about types of content that you may wish to leave untranslated.

concept.shortdesc: Learn how to organize your project to make localization easier.

section.title: Folder structure
section.p: A logical folder structure will make localization easier. Do not keep all your files in one folder. Instead, create separate folders for your topics, images, and other content.To avoid publishing problems, always store your DITA maps at a level above your topics and images.

section.title: Prefixes vs. folders
section.p: It is common practice to prefix topic names with "c_", "t_", "r_," and "_g" for concepts, tasks, references, and glossary entries, respectively. For example:
For larger projects, it may be useful to create separate folders for topics of each type (that is concepts, tasks, references, and glossary entries). This will make managing the project easier.

image.alt: A flow chart depicting basic project structure with separe folders for images and each type of topics

section.title: Language versions
section.p: To make the localization process easier, create a separate subfolder for each language version. Each subfolder should have the same structure.

image.alt: A flow chart depicting project structure divided into separe folders for different language versions

section.title: Untranslated files
section.p: Some files, such as images and other content, will be shared among language versions. They don't need to be translated. It's a good idea to keep files you don't want to translate in a separate folder.

image.alt: A flow chart depicting project structure divided into separe folders for different language versions and a common folder for untranslated files

Learn how to quickly replace content references and key references with content.

task.shortdesc: Learn how to quickly replace content references and key references with content.

taskbody.context: When preparing your project for localization, it may be useful to replace content references (conrefs) and key references (keyrefs) with appropriate content. To resolve all conrefs and keyrefs in a topic, follow these steps:

step.cmd: Open a topic containing references and switch to the Author mode.
Go to DITAReplace All References with Content.

image.alt: 'DITA' menu in oXygen with the 'Replace All References with Content' option

taskbody.result: All references in the topic are replaced with relevant content. A comparison of DITA code before and after resolving references. All references are replaced with appropriate content.

title.ph: Importing a DITA project into memoQ

task.shortdesc: Learn how to import your DITA project into memoQ while preserving the project's folder structure.

context.p: When translating a DITA project, it is important to preserve the relationships between files. To import your project into memoQ without losing the project's folder strucure, follow these steps:

step.cmd: In the New memoQ project dialog, enter the Name of the project.

image.alt: Choosing a language pair in 'New memoQ project' dialog

step.cmd: Enter the Client and any optional details, then click Next.
In the Translation memories step, choose or create a translation memory.
In the Term bases step, choose or create a term base.
Click … next to the Base path field, choose the folder where your project is located, and click OK.

image.alt: The 'Add folder structure' dialog in memoQ

step.cmd: In the Document import options dialog, remove any files you don't want to translate.

image.alt: The 'Document import options' dialog in memoQ

taskbody.result: Project files are ready for translation. DITA project imported into memoQ To export a translated project, right-click on the root folder and choose ExportExport (Stored Path).

link.desc: Learn how to organize your project to make localization easier.
Learn how to simplify your translation process in memoQ by creating a view containing only repetitions.
Learn how to simplify your translation process in memoQ by creating a view containing only repetitions.

task.shortdesc: Learn how to simplify your translation process in memoQ by creating a view containing only repetitions.

taskbody.context: If your DITA project contains a lot of repetitive content, it may be useful to include all repetitions in one view. In order to create a view containing all repetitions, follow these steps:

step.cmd: Go to Project homeTranslations and select all files.
Right-click the files and choose Create View.

image.alt: The 'Create View' option in memoQ 'Translations' screen

step.cmd: In the Create view dialog, enter the Name of the view, select Extract repetitions, and click OK.

taskbody.result: You can work on a view containing all repeating segments in your project. An example memoQ view containing repetitions
